Reference¶

MiniZinc tools¶

PyMzn provides functions that mimic and enhance the tools from the libminizinc library. With those tools it is possible to compile a MiniZinc model into FlatZinc, solve a given problem and get the output solutions directly into the python code.

minizinc(mzn, *dzn_files[, data, keep, ...]) Main function of the library.
mzn2fzn(mzn_file, *dzn_files[, data, ...]) Flatten a MiniZinc model into a FlatZinc one.
solns2out(solns_input, ozn_file) Wraps the solns2out utility, executes it on the input solution stream, and then returns the output.

Modelling¶

MiniZincModel([mzn]) Mutable class representing minizinc model.

Solvers¶

gecode(fzn_file, *[, time, parallel, ...]) Solves a constrained optimization problem using the Gecode solver, provided a .fzn input problem file.
optimatsat(fzn_file)
solve(fzn_file[, solver_cmd])

Dzn files¶

Utilities to convert Python objects into dzn format and back.

parse_dzn(dzn, *[, rebase_arrays]) Parse one or more pieces of dzn strings.
dzn(objs[, fout]) Serializes the objects in input and produces a list of strings encoding them into the dzn format.
dzn_value(val) Serializes a value (bool, int, float, set, array) into its dzn representation.
rebase_array(d) Transform an indexed dictionary (such as those returned by the parse_dzn function when parsing arrays) into an multi-dimensional list.

Errors¶

MiniZincUnsatisfiableError() Error raised when a minizinc problem is found to be unsatisfiable.
MiniZincUnknownError() Error raised when minizinc returns no solution (unknown).
MiniZincUnboundedError() Error raised when a minizinc problem is found to be unbounded.
